unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Rolling Doubles: What are the Chances?
question_text:
When two fair, $6$-sided dice are tossed, the result is called “doubles” if both dice land with the same number of dots showing (for example, both dice land with $3\text{ dots}$ showing).
What is the probability that when tossing two dice, more than $4\text{ tosses}$ will be needed in order to get doubles for the first time?
solution:
We are looking for $p(x>4)$, where $x$ is the number of rolls required in order to get “doubles” for the first time. We can approach this in two ways.

The first approach is easiest and uses the formula:

$$p(x>k)=(1-p)^{k}$$

$$p(x>4)={ \left( 1-\dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) }^{ 4 }=0.4823$$

We can get the same answer using the complement principle. That is:

$$p(x>4)=1-p(x\le4)=1-[p(x=1)+p(x=2)+p(x=3)+p(x=4)]$$

Plug in numbers:

$$p(x>4)=1-\left[ \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) +\left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) +\left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) +\left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 5 }{ 6 } \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ 6 } \right) \right] =0.4823$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the $4^\text{th}\text{ roll}$ of the dice will be the first roll of doubles.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. It represents the probability that exactly one roll of doubles will appear in $4\text{ rolls}$ of the dice and was calculated as a binomial probability.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. It represents the probability that the first roll of doubles will occur before the $4^\text{th}\text{ roll}$ of the dice. That is, on the first, second or third roll.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It is the complement of the correct answer.
